posts.cooked:
I‚Äôm not sure if anybody else has followed the news, but: WeTransfer attempted to change their ToS in such a way that users would basically relinquish the rights on anything sent through the service so that WeTransfer can use it to train AI models. And now they‚Äôre attempting to crawl back‚Ä¶

Some links:

  • @bagpuss.org on Bluesky
  • https://web.archive.org/web/20250715072652/https://wetransfer.com/explore/legal/terms

I‚Äôve never heard of this company .

In these here parts it used to be the go-to service to share files, such as full quality photos. Photographers also use it to send photos to their clients.
More proof that anything that isn‚Äôt e2e encrypted just isn‚Äôt good enough.

mcc (@mcc@mastodon.social)

Hey, Computer People. There was a fire drill with "WeTransfer" with WeTransfer granting themselves some potentially expansive explicit IP rights to files transferred over their service in a new TOS, then backpedaling when people got upset. Bluesky...
